question.title: [Metaculus] Will Joe Biden announce before July 15, 2024 that he will not accept the Democra...nomination for President?
question.body:
Will Joe Biden announce before July 15, 2024 that he will not accept the Democratic Party's nomination for President?

Resolves the same as the original on Metaculus.

(https://www.metaculus.com/questions/question_embed/25755/?theme=dark)Resolution criteria

This question will resolve as Yes if prior to 00:00 Eastern on July 15, 2024, Joe Biden or his campaign makes a definitive, public, official announcement to the effect that Joe Biden will not seek and will not accept the nomination of his party for another term as President of the United States in the 2024 cycle.

To qualify for a Yes resolution, the statement must be unambiguous and conclusive: it should leave no room for the possibility that Biden would accept the Democratic Party's nomination for President of the United States in the 2024 election cycle.

If such a definitive statement is not made prior to 00:00 Eastern on July 15, 2024, this question will resolve as No.

Fine print and additional background information can be found on Metaculus.

Once the original resolves, its resolution will be applied to this market automatically. Trustworthy-ish users are encouraged to resolve this market before then if the outcome is known and unambiguous. Feel free to ping @jskf to request early resolution or to report issues.

metadata.chain_of_thought: Joe Biden's decision regarding the 2024 Democratic nomination is influenced by various factors, including his health, the political landscape, and public opinion. As of now, he has not made any definitive announcements indicating he will not seek re-election, and there is a significant amount of time left before the resolution date. Historically, incumbents often seek re-election unless there are compelling reasons to step down. Given that Biden is the sitting president and has significant support from the Democratic Party, it seems more likely that he would continue his campaign efforts rather than announce a withdrawal. However, there are uncertainties, such as health concerns or political pressures, that could influence his decision. Overall, while there is a possibility that he might announce he will not accept the nomination, the likelihood appears to be low at this point, leading me to estimate a higher probability for the question resolving as NO.

question.title: If Joe Biden announces he will not accept the Democratic nomination, will Kamala Harris's odds of winning increase according to Nate Silver's model?
question.body:
Suppose the following is true: Joe Biden announces before July 15, 2024, that he will not accept the Democratic Party's nomination for President. This announcement must be definitive, unambiguous, and made publicly by Biden or his campaign, leaving no possibility of him accepting the nomination for the 2024 election.

Given this, will Kamala Harris's Electoral College probability in Nate Silver's model be greater than 46.6% on Friday, August 9th, at 8:40 PM? Resolves YES if it is >46.6% at that time, and NO otherwise.

This analysis considers the impact of Biden's decision on Harris's perceived chances in the model, as tracked on Nate Silver's platform.

metadata.chain_of_thought:
If Joe Biden definitively announces that he will not accept the Democratic nomination, it could significantly alter the dynamics of the Democratic primary race. Kamala Harris, as the sitting Vice President, would likely be viewed as a leading candidate for the nomination. This announcement would eliminate Biden as a contender, which could lead to an increase in support for Harris among Democratic voters, as she would be seen as a viable candidate without Biden in the race. 

Nate Silver's model typically incorporates polling data, historical trends, and other factors that influence candidate viability. If Harris gains traction and support following Biden's announcement, it is reasonable to expect that her odds of winning the nomination—and thus her Electoral College probability—would increase. 

Given the context of the announcement and the likely shifts in voter sentiment, it is quite plausible that Harris's probability of winning could exceed 46.6% after Biden's decision is made public. Therefore, I would estimate a high probability that her odds will indeed increase above this threshold.

question.title: Will both of the following occur: (a) Will Joe Biden announce before July 15, 2024 that he will not accept the Democratic Party's nomination for President? (b) Will Kamala's odds of winning increase over the next week according to Nate Silver's model?
question.body:
(a) Will Joe Biden announce before July 15, 2024 that he will not accept the Democratic Party's nomination for President? This resolves as Yes if prior to 00:00 Eastern on July 15, 2024, Joe Biden or his campaign makes a definitive, public, official announcement that he will not seek and will not accept the nomination of his party for another term as President of the United States in the 2024 cycle. The statement must be unambiguous and conclusive, leaving no room for the possibility that Biden would accept the Democratic Party's nomination for President in the 2024 election cycle. If such a definitive statement is not made prior to 00:00 Eastern on July 15, 2024, this question will resolve as No.

(b) Will Kamala's odds of winning increase over the next week according to Nate Silver's model? Resolves YES if the Electoral College probability for Harris in Nate Silver's model is >46.6% on Friday August 9th at 8:40 PM. Resolves NO otherwise. Link: https://www.natesilver.net/p/nate-silver-2024-president-election-polls-model

metadata.chain_of_thought:
To evaluate the likelihood of both conditions occurring, we need to consider the political landscape and the behavior of Joe Biden and Kamala Harris leading up to the 2024 election.

1. **Joe Biden's Announcement**: As of October 2023, Joe Biden has not made any definitive announcements regarding his candidacy for the 2024 election. Historically, sitting presidents tend to seek re-election unless there are significant health concerns, political pressures, or other compelling reasons not to. While there is speculation about Biden's age and approval ratings, the absence of a definitive announcement by now suggests that he is likely to remain in the race until closer to the election date. Therefore, the probability of him announcing that he will not accept the nomination before July 15, 2024, is relatively low.

2. **Kamala Harris's Odds**: Kamala Harris's odds of winning depend on various factors, including Biden's decisions, public sentiment, and the political environment. If Biden were to announce that he will not seek the nomination, it could significantly boost Harris's odds as she would be viewed as a frontrunner. However, if Biden remains in the race, it is less likely that her odds would increase significantly. Given that the question asks for a resolution in the week leading up to August 9, 2024, it is difficult to predict how the odds will shift without knowing Biden's decision.

In summary, the likelihood of both conditions occurring (Biden announcing he won't run and Harris's odds increasing) is quite low, especially since Biden's announcement is pivotal for Harris's odds to increase. Thus, I estimate the probability that both will occur as low.

question.title: Will Donald Trump be removed or blocked from the primary election ballot of any U.S. state for a federal office under Section 3 of the 14th Amendment?
question.body:
This question will resolve as "Yes" if, *on* July 15, 2024:

Donald Trump has been officially removed or blocked from the primary election ballot of any U.S. state for a federal office (President, Senate, House of Representatives) under the grounds of Section 3 of the 14th Amendment.

The removal or block is confirmed through official state government announcements, court decisions, legal documentation, or credible media reports. Speculative reports, opinion pieces, or unofficial announcements will not suffice for resolution.

The question will resolve as "No" if these conditions are not met as of July 15, 2024.

Note: The question does not account for legal battles, appeals, or subsequent reversals that might occur *after* the mentioned date. It strictly pertains to whether Donald Trump has been removed from any state's primary election ballot for a federal office under the specified grounds as of July 15, 2024. If Trump is removed or blocked from a ballot and then reinstated, such that as of July 15th he is not removed or blocked from any ballot, the question resolves negatively.

metadata.chain_of_thought: The question revolves around the application of Section 3 of the 14th Amendment, which disqualifies individuals from holding office if they have engaged in insurrection or rebellion against the United States. While there has been significant discussion about whether this provision could apply to Donald Trump due to the events surrounding January 6, 2021, the actual implementation of such disqualification is complex and would require state-level actions or judicial rulings. Historically, attempts to disqualify candidates using this provision have faced significant legal hurdles and challenges. As of now, there has been no definitive legal ruling that would lead to Trump's removal from a primary ballot under these grounds. Moreover, political dynamics, including the influence of his supporters within state Republican parties and potential legal defenses he could mount, further complicate the likelihood of such an outcome. Given the political landscape and the legal complexities involved, it seems unlikely that any state will successfully remove or block Trump from the primary ballot under Section 3 of the 14th Amendment by the specified date.

question.title: Given Donald Trump is removed or blocked from a primary ballot under Section 3 of the 14th Amendment, will he be the Republican nominee for the 2024 US Presidential Election?
question.body:
Suppose the following is true: Donald Trump has been officially removed or blocked from the primary election ballot of any U.S. state for a federal office under Section 3 of the 14th Amendment, as of July 15, 2024. This removal or block must be confirmed through official state government announcements, court decisions, legal documentation, or credible media reports, and is not reversed by that date.

Then, is it true that Donald Trump will be selected by the Republican National Convention as the nominee for the 2024 US Presidential Election? The resolution is based on the decision made by the delegates of the Republican National Convention, regardless of the eventual outcome of the 2024 US election.

metadata.chain_of_thought: If Donald Trump is officially removed or blocked from the primary ballot under Section 3 of the 14th Amendment, it would significantly hinder his ability to secure the Republican nomination for the 2024 Presidential Election. The Republican National Convention delegates typically choose a nominee based on the results of the primaries, where candidates compete for delegates through state elections. If Trump cannot appear on the ballot, he would not be able to win any delegates, making it virtually impossible for him to be nominated. The Republican Party has a strong incentive to select a candidate who can compete in the general election, and without a presence in the primaries, Trump's chances of being nominated would be exceedingly low. Therefore, the probability that he will be the nominee, given that he is blocked from the ballot, is very small.

question.title: Will both of the following occur: (1) Donald Trump is removed or blocked from the primary election ballot of any U.S. state for a federal office under Section 3 of the 14th Amendment by July 15, 2024, and (2) Donald Trump is the Republican nominee for the 2024 US Presidential Election?
question.body:
This question will resolve as "Yes" if both of the following conditions are met:

1. As of July 15, 2024, Donald Trump has been officially removed or blocked from the primary election ballot of any U.S. state for a federal office (President, Senate, House of Representatives) under the grounds of Section 3 of the 14th Amendment. The removal or block must be confirmed through official state government announcements, court decisions, legal documentation, or credible media reports. Speculative reports, opinion pieces, or unofficial announcements will not suffice for resolution. Note that the question does not account for legal battles, appeals, or subsequent reversals that might occur after the mentioned date. It strictly pertains to whether Donald Trump has been removed from any state's primary election ballot for a federal office under the specified grounds as of July 15, 2024. If Trump is removed or blocked from a ballot and then reinstated, such that as of July 15th he is not removed or blocked from any ballot, the question resolves negatively.

2. Donald Trump is selected by the Republican National Convention as the nominee for the 2024 US Presidential Election. It is not relevant who receives the Republican nomination on the day of the 2024 US election; it is solely determined by who is selected by the delegates of the Republican National Convention.

The question will resolve as "No" if either or both of these conditions are not met.

metadata.chain_of_thought: The question hinges on two significant events occurring simultaneously with specific legal and political implications. 1. **Section 3 of the 14th Amendment**: This section pertains to disqualifying individuals from holding office if they have engaged in insurrection or rebellion against the United States. For Trump to be removed from the ballot under this provision, there would need to be a legal process affirming such disqualification. While there have been discussions and some legal challenges regarding Trump's eligibility, as of now, there is no definitive legal ruling that would lead to his removal from any state ballot by the specified date. The political and legal landscape is highly contentious, and while certain states may attempt to block him, such actions would likely face significant legal challenges and public pushback. 2. **Republican Nomination**: The Republican National Convention will take place in mid-2024, and Trump remains a strong figure within the Republican Party. Despite various controversies, he has substantial support among the party base, making it likely that he will be nominated unless significant shifts occur within the party dynamics or an unforeseen candidate emerges who can rally enough delegate support against him. Given these considerations, while there is a possibility that legal challenges could lead to Trump's removal from the ballot, the political reality suggests that he has a strong chance of being nominated by the Republican Party. However, the uncertainty surrounding legal processes makes the occurrence of both events less likely.

question.title: Will Donald Trump Jr. be the Republican nominee for the 2024 US Presidential Election?
question.body:
This question will resolve as **Yes** if Donald Trump Jr. is selected by the Republican National Convention as the nominee for the 2024 US Presidential Election. All other candidates will resolve as **No**. This question is not restricted to the candidates currently mentioned; other options may be added in the future.

For this question, it is not relevant who receives the Republican nomination on the day of the 2024 US election; it is solely determined by who is selected by the delegates of the [Republican National Convention](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Republican_National_Convention).

metadata.chain_of_thought: Donald Trump Jr. has been a prominent figure in Republican politics, largely due to his family's influence and his father's previous presidency. However, as of now, he has not officially declared his candidacy for the 2024 Presidential Election, and there are several other potential candidates, including established politicians and other Trump family members. The Republican National Convention will also consider various factors such as polling data, party dynamics, and the political landscape as the election approaches. Given the current state of affairs, while Trump Jr. has a notable profile, the likelihood of him being the nominee is uncertain, especially with other strong contenders potentially entering the race. Therefore, the probability that he will be the nominee is relatively low.

question.title: Conditional on Donald Trump Jr. being the Republican nominee, will Asa Hutchinson be the Republican nominee for the 2024 US Presidential Election?
question.body:
This question resolves as **Yes** if Donald Trump Jr. is selected by the Republican National Convention as the nominee for the 2024 US Presidential Election. If this condition is met, then the question resolves as **No** for Asa Hutchinson, as only one candidate can be the nominee.

Resolution criteria for the condition: Donald Trump Jr. must be selected by the delegates of the Republican National Convention as the nominee.
Resolution criteria for the outcome: Asa Hutchinson must be selected by the delegates of the Republican National Convention as the nominee, which is impossible if Donald Trump Jr. is the nominee. Therefore, if Donald Trump Jr. is the nominee, this resolves as **No**.

metadata.chain_of_thought: The question is contingent upon Donald Trump Jr. being the Republican nominee for the 2024 US Presidential Election. If he is indeed selected as the nominee by the Republican National Convention, it is impossible for Asa Hutchinson to also be the nominee, as there can only be one nominee from each party. Therefore, if Trump Jr. is the nominee, the question will resolve as **No** for Asa Hutchinson. Given the phrasing of the question and the clear implication that Asa Hutchinson cannot be the nominee if Trump Jr. is, the probability of the question resolving as **Yes** is effectively zero.

question.title: Will both Donald Trump Jr. and Asa Hutchinson be the Republican nominees for the 2024 US Presidential Election?
question.body:
This question will resolve as **Yes** if both Donald Trump Jr. and Asa Hutchinson are selected by the Republican National Convention as nominees for the 2024 US Presidential Election. All other combinations of candidates will resolve as **No**. This question is not restricted to the candidates currently mentioned; other options may be added in the future.

For this question, it is not relevant who receives the Republican nomination on the day of the 2024 US election; it is solely determined by who is selected by the delegates of the [Republican National Convention](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Republican_National_Convention).

metadata.chain_of_thought: The likelihood of both Donald Trump Jr. and Asa Hutchinson being the Republican nominees for the 2024 US Presidential Election is quite low. Donald Trump Jr. has not officially declared his candidacy, and while he has a strong following due to his family name, the political landscape is highly competitive, with many established figures in the Republican Party potentially running or already declaring their candidacies. Asa Hutchinson, on the other hand, is a less prominent figure compared to others like Donald Trump (the former president) and Ron DeSantis. Given the dynamics of the Republican primaries, it is improbable that both of these individuals will emerge as the nominees. The Republican National Convention typically sees a consolidation around more prominent candidates, and the presence of other strong contenders further diminishes the likelihood of this specific outcome. Therefore, the probability of both being nominated is quite low.

question.title: Will Joe Biden die before Saturday?
question.body:
Resolves YES if there is an official announcement of Joe Biden's death before market close at the end of Friday, July 26th. 

Otherwise, resolves NO.

metadata.chain_of_thought: Evaluating the likelihood of Joe Biden's death before the specified date involves considering various factors, including his current health status, age, and the general unpredictability of life. As of my last knowledge update in October 2023, Joe Biden was in his 80s, which naturally raises concerns about health, but he has also been actively engaged in public life and fulfilling his duties as President. Additionally, there are no significant health crises or announcements that indicate imminent risk to his life. Given these considerations, while it is impossible to predict life events with certainty, the probability of an official announcement of his death occurring before the specified date is low. Therefore, I estimate that the probability of the question resolving YES is quite small.

question.title: If Joe Biden dies before Saturday, will he remain President through the end of July 2024?
question.body:
Suppose the following is true: Joe Biden dies before Saturday, with an official announcement of his death made before market close at the end of Friday, July 26th. 

Resolution criteria for the condition: Resolves YES if there is an official announcement of Joe Biden's death before market close at the end of Friday, July 26th. Otherwise, resolves NO.

Resolution criteria for the outcome: Resolves YES if Biden remains US President through the end of July 2024 (ET); resolves NO if he resigns, dies, or otherwise ceases to be President before then. Temporary transfer of power under the 25th amendment (i.e., making his VP the Acting President) does not cause a YES resolution. (Acting President is different from President under the Constitution)

If the condition is not met, resolves N/A.

metadata.chain_of_thought: The question hinges on two conditions: first, the hypothetical scenario that Joe Biden dies before Saturday, and second, whether he can remain President through the end of July 2024. If Biden were to die before the specified time, the immediate consequence would be that he could not remain President. The resolution criteria state that the question resolves YES only if Biden remains President through the end of July 2024. Given that if he dies, he cannot fulfill the role of President, this makes it impossible for the question to resolve YES. Therefore, the probability that the question resolves YES is effectively zero.

question.title: Will Joe Biden die before Saturday and remain President through end of July 2024?
question.body:
Resolves YES if both of the following occur: (a) There is an official announcement of Joe Biden's death before market close at the end of Friday, July 26th, and (b) Biden remains US President through the end of July 2024 (ET).

Resolves NO if either Joe Biden does not die before the specified time or he does not remain President through the specified time. Temporary transfer of power under the 25th amendment does not affect the resolution regarding his presidency.

metadata.chain_of_thought: To assess the probability of Joe Biden dying before July 26, 2024, and remaining President through the end of July 2024, we need to consider several factors. First, Joe Biden's age and health are significant considerations; he was born in 1942, making him 81 years old in 2024. Advanced age can correlate with increased health risks, but it is also important to note that many individuals in their 80s maintain good health and continue to serve in public office. Next, the requirement for an official announcement of his death before the market close on July 26 adds another layer of complexity. The timing of such an announcement is uncertain and would depend on numerous factors, including any unexpected health complications that could arise. Furthermore, for Biden to remain President through the end of July 2024, he would need to survive until that date regardless of any health issues that might arise. Given the current political climate and the stability of the U.S. government, it is unlikely that there would be a sudden and unexpected death that would lead to an official announcement within the specified timeframe. Considering all these factors, while there is always a risk associated with health and age, the probabilities suggest that it is highly unlikely for both conditions (his death and remaining President) to occur as specified.

question.title: Kamala president by Friday?
question.body:
This market will resolve to "Yes" if Vice President Kamala Harris is formally designated as President or Acting President of the United States at any point before July 26, 2024, 11:59 PM ET. Otherwise, this market will resolve to "No".

The primary resolution source for this market will be official information from the US government, however a consensus of credible reporting will also be used.

Resolver

metadata.chain_of_thought:
To assess the probability of Kamala Harris being formally designated as President or Acting President by the specified date, we need to consider the political landscape and the mechanisms of presidential succession. As of now, Kamala Harris is the Vice President, and for her to become President or Acting President, a significant event such as the resignation, removal, or incapacitation of the current President would need to occur. 

Historically, such transitions happen under extraordinary circumstances, and there is no indication that President Biden is likely to resign or be removed from office within the time frame given. Additionally, while there may be political maneuvering and speculation, the formal designation as President or Acting President typically requires clear and substantial reasons, often involving constitutional processes.

Given the current political stability and the lack of any imminent threats to the President's position, the probability of Kamala Harris being designated as President or Acting President before the specified date is quite low.

question.title: Given Kamala Harris is president by Friday, will Biden drop out before July 20?
question.body:
Suppose the following is true: Vice President Kamala Harris is formally designated as President or Acting President of the United States at any point before July 26, 2024, 11:59 PM ET. This would be confirmed by official information from the US government or a consensus of credible reporting.

Then, is it true that President Joe Biden will drop out or be otherwise unable to continue the race before July 20 midnight Eastern Time? If he does, the answer is yes; otherwise, it is no.

metadata.chain_of_thought: Reasoning: The scenario presented suggests that Kamala Harris will be designated as President or Acting President before July 26, 2024. If this occurs, it could indicate a significant shift in the political landscape, potentially leading to Joe Biden's withdrawal from the race. However, the timing of Biden's decision is crucial. If he drops out before July 20, it implies that there has been enough political pressure or a compelling reason for him to step aside. Factors influencing this could include public opinion, party dynamics, or health concerns. Given the current political climate, where Biden has faced criticism and challenges, the possibility of him dropping out cannot be dismissed entirely. However, Biden has also shown resilience and a commitment to his candidacy. Therefore, while there is a reasonable chance he could drop out, it is not overwhelmingly likely.

question.title: Will both of the following occur: (a) Kamala Harris is President or Acting President by July 26, 2024, and (b) Biden drops out before July 20, 2024?
question.body:
(a) Kamala Harris is formally designated as President or Acting President of the United States at any point before July 26, 2024, 11:59 PM ET. The primary resolution source will be official information from the US government, however a consensus of credible reporting will also be used.

(b) Joe Biden drops out or is otherwise unable to continue the race before July 20, 2024, midnight Eastern Time.

metadata.chain_of_thought: To assess the likelihood of both events occurring, we need to consider the political context and the current status of both Kamala Harris and Joe Biden. As of October 2023, Joe Biden is the incumbent president and has announced his intention to run for re-election. The probability of him dropping out of the race is relatively low, given that he has significant support within the Democratic Party and the infrastructure in place for his campaign. However, for Kamala Harris to become President or Acting President, there are several scenarios: Biden could resign, be incapacitated, or be removed from office, but these scenarios are generally considered unlikely. Additionally, if Biden were to drop out, it is more probable that the Democratic Party would select another candidate rather than appointing Harris as Acting President unless there were extraordinary circumstances. Given these considerations, while there is a possibility that both events could occur, the combination of Biden dropping out and Harris taking over before the specified dates is quite low.

question.title: Will Donald Trump be removed or blocked from the primary election ballot of any U.S. state for a federal office under Section 3 of the 14th Amendment?
question.body:
This question will resolve as "Yes" if, *on* July 15, 2024:

Donald Trump has been officially removed or blocked from the primary election ballot of any U.S. state for a federal office (President, Senate, House of Representatives) under the grounds of Section 3 of the 14th Amendment.

The removal or block is confirmed through official state government announcements, court decisions, legal documentation, or credible media reports. Speculative reports, opinion pieces, or unofficial announcements will not suffice for resolution.

The question will resolve as "No" if these conditions are not met as of July 15, 2024.

Note: The question does not account for legal battles, appeals, or subsequent reversals that might occur *after* the mentioned date. It strictly pertains to whether Donald Trump has been removed from any state's primary election ballot for a federal office under the specified grounds as of July 15, 2024. If Trump is removed or blocked from a ballot and then reinstated, such that as of July 15th he is not removed or blocked from any ballot, the question resolves negatively.

metadata.chain_of_thought: The question revolves around the potential application of Section 3 of the 14th Amendment, which disqualifies individuals from holding office if they have engaged in insurrection or rebellion against the United States. The likelihood of Donald Trump being removed from the primary election ballot in any U.S. state under this amendment hinges on several factors, including ongoing legal challenges, political dynamics, and public sentiment leading up to the 2024 elections. Therefore, I estimate the probability of the question resolving YES to be low.

question.title: Given Donald Trump is removed from any primary ballot under the 14th Amendment, will Ted Cruz be the Republican nominee for 2024?
question.body:
Suppose the following is true: Donald Trump has been officially removed or blocked from the primary election ballot of any U.S. state for a federal office under Section 3 of the 14th Amendment, as confirmed by official state government announcements, court decisions, legal documentation, or credible media reports, by July 15, 2024. This does not consider legal battles, appeals, or reversals after this date.

Then, will Ted Cruz be selected by the Republican National Convention as the nominee for the 2024 US Presidential Election? This is determined solely by the selection of the delegates of the Republican National Convention, regardless of who receives the nomination on the day of the 2024 US election.

metadata.chain_of_thought: If Donald Trump is removed from the primary ballot under the 14th Amendment, the Republican Party will likely face a significant shift in its primary dynamics. Trump has been a dominant figure within the party, and his absence would create an open field for other candidates. Ted Cruz, being a prominent Republican figure with previous presidential campaign experience, could capitalize on this opportunity. However, Cruz's chances would depend on several factors, including his appeal to the Republican base, the emergence of other candidates, and the overall political landscape closer to the convention. While he has a solid support base, there are other potential candidates who may also vie for the nomination, such as Ron DeSantis or Nikki Haley, among others. The Republican National Convention delegates would ultimately decide the nominee, and while Cruz could be a frontrunner, it is uncertain whether he would secure enough delegate support to win the nomination outright. Therefore, while Cruz's chances improve significantly if Trump is not in the race, they are not guaranteed. Given these considerations, I would estimate a moderate probability that Ted Cruz becomes the Republican nominee, but it is not overwhelmingly likely.

question.title: Will Donald Trump be removed from the primary election ballot of any U.S. state for a federal office under Section 3 of the 14th Amendment by July 15, 2024, and will Ted Cruz be the Republican nominee for the 2024 US Presidential Election?
question.body:
This question will resolve as "Yes" if both of the following conditions are met:

1. As of July 15, 2024, Donald Trump has been officially removed or blocked from the primary election ballot of any U.S. state for a federal office (President, Senate, House of Representatives) under the grounds of Section 3 of the 14th Amendment. This removal or block must be confirmed through official state government announcements, court decisions, legal documentation, or credible media reports. Speculative reports, opinion pieces, or unofficial announcements will not suffice. The question does not account for legal battles, appeals, or subsequent reversals that might occur after the mentioned date. It strictly pertains to whether Donald Trump has been removed from any state's primary election ballot for a federal office under the specified grounds as of July 15, 2024. If Trump is removed or blocked from a ballot and then reinstated, such that as of July 15th he is not removed or blocked from any ballot, this condition is not met.

2. Ted Cruz is selected by the Republican National Convention as the nominee for the 2024 US Presidential Election. The resolution of this condition is based solely on the selection by the delegates of the Republican National Convention, regardless of who receives the Republican nomination on the day of the 2024 US election.

The question will resolve as "No" if either or both of these conditions are not met.

metadata.chain_of_thought:
The question hinges on two separate and significant events occurring before July 15, 2024. The first condition requires that Donald Trump be officially removed from the primary election ballot in any U.S. state under Section 3 of the 14th Amendment. This provision has been a topic of legal and political debate, especially following the events of January 6, 2021. However, as of now, there has been no definitive legal ruling that suggests Trump will be removed from the ballot under this amendment. Legal challenges and political maneuvers could arise, but the likelihood of a successful removal is uncertain and would require significant legal precedent or a shift in the political landscape.

The second condition requires Ted Cruz to be selected as the Republican nominee at the National Convention. As of now, Cruz has not declared his candidacy for the 2024 election, and the Republican field is likely to be competitive. Given Trump's strong base within the Republican Party, it is challenging to predict that Cruz will emerge as the nominee, especially if Trump remains a candidate.

Both conditions are interdependent, and the probability of both occurring by the specified date is low. Therefore, the likelihood of the question resolving as "Yes" is also low.

question.title: Will Vivek Ramaswamy be the Republican nominee for the 2024 US Presidential Election?
question.body:
This question will resolve as **Yes** if Vivek Ramaswamy is selected by the Republican National Convention as the nominee for the 2024 US Presidential Election. All other candidates will resolve as **No**. This question is not restricted to the candidates currently below; other options may be added in the future.

For this question, it is not relevant who receives the Republican nomination on the day of the 2024 US election; it is solely determined by who is selected by the delegates of the [Republican National Convention](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Republican_National_Convention).

metadata.chain_of_thought:
Reasoning: Vivek Ramaswamy is a relatively new figure in the Republican political landscape, having announced his candidacy for the 2024 presidential election. As of now, he is one of several candidates competing for the Republican nomination. The nomination process involves primaries and caucuses, culminating in the Republican National Convention where delegates will cast their votes. Factors that influence his chances include his political experience, fundraising ability, public perception, and performance in debates and primaries.

Currently, he is not leading in polls against more established candidates, such as Donald Trump and Ron DeSantis, who have a stronger base of support and name recognition. While Ramaswamy has gained some traction, the competition is fierce. Given the current political landscape and the dynamics of the Republican Party, it seems unlikely that he would secure the nomination over more prominent candidates. Therefore, the probability of him being the nominee is relatively low.

question.title: Conditional on Vivek Ramaswamy being the Republican nominee for the 2024 US Presidential Election, will Mike Pence be the nominee?
question.body:
This question will resolve as **No** if Vivek Ramaswamy is selected by the Republican National Convention as the nominee for the 2024 US Presidential Election, because only one candidate can be the nominee. 

Resolution criteria: The outcome is determined by who is selected by the delegates of the [Republican National Convention](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Republican_National_Convention).

metadata.chain_of_thought: The question asks about the likelihood of Mike Pence being the nominee for the Republican Party in the 2024 US Presidential Election, conditional on Vivek Ramaswamy being the nominee. Since only one candidate can be the nominee, if Ramaswamy is indeed selected as the nominee, it inherently means that Mike Pence cannot be the nominee. Given the structure of the question, if Ramaswamy is confirmed as the nominee, the answer will unequivocally be "No" for Pence. Therefore, the probability that the question resolves with "Yes" (that Pence will also be the nominee) is effectively zero, as the two scenarios are mutually exclusive.

question.title: Will both Vivek Ramaswamy and Mike Pence be selected as the Republican nominees for the 2024 US Presidential Election?
question.body:
This question will resolve as **Yes** if both Vivek Ramaswamy and Mike Pence are selected by the Republican National Convention as the nominees for the 2024 US Presidential Election. All other candidates or combinations of candidates will resolve as **No**. This question is not restricted to the candidates currently below; other options may be added in the future.

For this question, it is not relevant who receives the Republican nomination on the day of the 2024 US election; it is solely determined by who is selected by the delegates of the [Republican National Convention](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Republican_National_Convention).

metadata.chain_of_thought: The Republican National Convention is a key event where the delegates officially select the party's nominees for the presidential election. As of now, both Vivek Ramaswamy and Mike Pence are candidates in the Republican primary. However, the political landscape can change rapidly, and many factors will influence who the delegates ultimately select, including polling data, endorsements, and the overall dynamics of the primary race. Given that the Republican Party has a history of consolidating support around fewer candidates as the primaries progress, the likelihood of both Ramaswamy and Pence being selected as nominees appears low. It is more probable that one or both may be eliminated in favor of a leading candidate, especially if another candidate emerges as a strong front-runner. Therefore, the probability of both being selected as the nominees is quite small.

question.title: Will the USA win more Gold than Silver medals at the Paris 2024 Olympics?
question.body: This question resolves Yes if the United States Olympic Team wins more Gold medals than Silver medals at the Paris 2024 Olympics.

metadata.chain_of_thought: The United States has a strong history of performance in the Olympics, particularly in terms of winning medals. In previous Olympic Games, the U.S. has consistently secured more Gold medals than Silver medals. For instance, in the Tokyo 2020 Olympics, the U.S. won 39 Gold medals compared to 41 Silver medals, but this was an anomaly in a long-standing trend where Gold medals have typically outnumbered Silver medals. The U.S. Olympic Team has a robust infrastructure, extensive training programs, and a wide range of sports in which they excel. Given this historical context and the overall performance trends, it is reasonable to predict that the U.S. will likely win more Gold medals than Silver medals at the Paris 2024 Olympics.

question.title: Given the USA wins more Gold than Silver medals, will they top the Olympic Medal Table at Paris 2024?
question.body:
Suppose the following is true: The United States Olympic Team wins more Gold medals than Silver medals at the Paris 2024 Olympics. Then, will the USA be the (unique) highest ranked team at the 2024 Paris Olympics?

Resolution criteria for the condition: Resolves YES if the USA wins more Gold than Silver medals.
Resolution criteria for the outcome: Resolves positively if the USA is the (unique) highest ranked team at the 2024 Paris Olympics. Resolves ambiguously if the Paris Olympics do not take place before 2027. Resolves negatively if any team achieves a higher or equal ranking to the US team. The ranking is determined by the number of Gold, Silver, and Bronze medals in that order.

metadata.chain_of_thought: To determine the probability of the USA being the unique highest ranked team at the Paris 2024 Olympics given that they win more Gold medals than Silver medals, we need to consider several factors. 1. **Historical Performance**: The USA has a strong track record in the Olympics, often leading the medal count. Historically, the USA has frequently won more Gold medals than Silver medals, which suggests a pattern that could continue in 2024. 2. **Competition**: While the USA is a strong contender, other countries such as China, Russia, and Great Britain also have strong Olympic teams. If any of these countries perform exceptionally well, they could potentially match or exceed the USA's medal count, especially if they secure a higher number of Gold medals. 3. **Medal Count System**: The ranking system prioritizes Gold medals first, followed by Silver and then Bronze. If the USA achieves a higher number of Gold medals, it increases their chances of topping the medal table. However, if another country also wins a significant number of Gold medals, or if they win more Silver or Bronze medals, it could lead to a tie or a higher ranking for that country. 4. **Uncertainty of Future Events**: The outcome of the Olympics is uncertain due to various factors such as athlete performance, injuries, and other unforeseen circumstances. Given these considerations, while the USA winning more Gold than Silver increases their chances of being the highest ranked team, it does not guarantee it. The competitive nature of the Olympics and the performance of other countries introduce significant uncertainty. Therefore, while it is plausible that the USA could top the medal table, there is a considerable risk that other countries could match or exceed their performance.

question.title: Will the USA win more Gold than Silver medals and also top the Olympic Medal Table at the Paris 2024 Olympics?
question.body: This question resolves Yes if both of the following conditions are met: (a) The United States Olympic Team wins more Gold medals than Silver medals at the Paris 2024 Olympics. (b) The United States Olympic Team is the (unique) highest ranked team at the 2024 Paris Olympics. The ranking is determined by the number of Gold medals, followed by Silver, and then Bronze medals. The question resolves ambiguously if the Paris Olympics do not take place before 2027. It resolves negatively if either condition (a) or (b) is not met.

metadata.chain_of_thought:
The United States has a strong historical performance in the Olympics, often leading in both the total medal count and the gold medal count. In recent Olympics, the USA consistently wins a significant number of gold medals, often surpassing silver medals. For instance, in the Tokyo 2020 Olympics, the USA won 39 gold medals compared to 41 silver medals, but this was an outlier as the USA typically has a higher gold count. Given the depth of talent in various sports, the USA is likely to win more gold medals than silver in Paris 2024.

Regarding the overall medal table, the USA has been the top nation in terms of gold medals in most Olympics, and there is no indication this trend will change, especially with the ongoing investment in training and athlete development. However, other countries like China and Russia have been competitive, which could affect the outcome.

Considering these factors, while there are uncertainties, the likelihood that the USA will win more gold medals than silver and also top the medal table is relatively high.

question.title: Will Donald Trump Jr. be the Republican nominee for the 2024 US Presidential Election?
question.body:
This question will resolve as **Yes** if Donald Trump Jr. is selected by the Republican National Convention as the nominee for the 2024 US Presidential Election. All other candidates will resolve as **No**. This question is not restricted to the candidates currently mentioned; other options may be added in the future.

For this question, it is not relevant who receives the Republican nomination on the day of the 2024 US election; it is solely determined by who is selected by the delegates of the [Republican National Convention](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Republican_National_Convention).

metadata.chain_of_thought: As of now, Donald Trump Jr. is not a declared candidate for the Republican nomination for the 2024 US Presidential Election. The political landscape is highly dynamic, and while he may have some support due to his family's prominence in Republican politics, several other potential candidates have already emerged, including established figures like former President Donald Trump, Florida Governor Ron DeSantis, and former Vice President Mike Pence. Additionally, the Republican National Convention will consider a wide range of candidates, and the nomination process involves significant campaigning and delegate support, which can be unpredictable. Given the current situation and the competition he would face, the probability of Donald Trump Jr. being the nominee appears low.

question.title: Conditional on Donald Trump Jr. being the Republican nominee for the 2024 US Presidential Election, will Nikki Haley be the nominee?
question.body:
This question will resolve as **Yes** if both Donald Trump Jr. and Nikki Haley are selected by the Republican National Convention as co-nominees for the 2024 US Presidential Election, which is highly unlikely given the nature of the nomination process. All other outcomes will resolve as **No**.

Resolution Criteria for Condition: Donald Trump Jr. must be selected by the delegates of the Republican National Convention as the nominee for the 2024 US Presidential Election.
Resolution Criteria for Outcome: Nikki Haley must be selected by the delegates of the Republican National Convention as the nominee for the 2024 US Presidential Election.

If the condition is not met, this question resolves as N/A.

metadata.chain_of_thought: Reasoning: The question hinges on two main factors: the likelihood of Donald Trump Jr. being chosen as the Republican nominee and the likelihood of Nikki Haley being chosen as a co-nominee alongside him. As of my last knowledge update in October 2023, Donald Trump Jr. has not been a prominent candidate in the Republican primaries, and there are several other strong contenders, including established political figures and former officials. The Republican nomination process typically favors candidates with significant political experience and established support within the party. Moreover, the concept of co-nomination is quite rare in U.S. presidential elections. The Republican National Convention usually selects a single nominee, and while it is theoretically possible for two individuals to be nominated together, it is highly unlikely given the party's traditional nomination process and the competitive nature of the primaries. Given these considerations, the probability that both Donald Trump Jr. and Nikki Haley are selected as co-nominees seems very low, leading me to conclude that the question will likely resolve as NO. Therefore, I estimate the probability of the question resolving YES as very low.

question.title: Given Donald Trump Jr. is the Republican nominee, will Chris Christie also be the nominee for the 2024 US Presidential Election?

question.title: Conditional on Donald Trump being the Republican nominee, will Francis Suarez also be the nominee?

metadata.chain_of_thought: The question hinges on the outcome of the Republican National Convention and specifically the nomination of Chris Christie. question.title: Will at least 20 House/Senate Democrats sign a public letter opposing the plan to virtually nominate Biden early?
question.body:
Context from Politico:

Dozens of House Democrats are organizing a plan to speak out against their own party’s effort to seal President Joe Biden’s nomination sooner than originally planned, which they argue stifles the intense ongoing debate about his candidacy, according to a lawmaker involved in the effort.

A drafted letter, circulated by Rep. Jared Huffman (D-Calif.) and obtained by POLITICO, offers the first public signal from Democrats since the weekend’s attempted assassination on former President Donald Trump that scores of their own members remain deeply unsettled about the future of Biden’s candidacy.

“It’s a really bad move by the DNC. Somebody thinks it’s a clever way to lock down debate and I guess by dint of sheer force, achieve unity, but it doesn’t work that way,” Huffman said in an interview. He declined to confirm the existence of a letter.

This market resolves YES if a public letter opposing the early nomination plan is signed by at least 20 House Members or Senators who caucus with the Democratic Party before market close at the end of Sunday, July 21st. 

Multiple such letters with a combined total of 20 lawmaker's signatures would also be sufficient to resolve this market to YES. 

If these criteria are not met by market close, this market resolves NO.

metadata.chain_of_thought: The context indicates that there is a significant push among House Democrats to oppose the early nomination of President Biden. The drafted letter, led by Rep. Jared Huffman, signals that there is a considerable level of dissent concerning the DNC's strategy. Given that this initiative has already garnered attention and is being actively organized, it suggests that there is a strong motivation among Democrats to express their concerns publicly. Moreover, the fact that the letter is being circulated implies that it is likely to attract support from other lawmakers who share similar sentiments. Considering the size of the Democratic caucus in both the House and Senate, securing at least 20 signatures seems plausible, especially since multiple letters could also fulfill the requirement. Given these factors, I assess that there is a high probability that at least 20 House/Senate Democrats will sign a public letter opposing the early nomination plan.

question.title: Given at least 20 House/Senate Democrats sign a public letter opposing Biden's early nomination, will 10 or more Democratic Senators call for Biden to drop out before July 20?
question.body:
Context from Politico:

Dozens of House Democrats are organizing a plan to speak out against their own party’s effort to seal President Joe Biden’s nomination sooner than originally planned, which they argue stifles the intense ongoing debate about his candidacy, according to a lawmaker involved in the effort.

A drafted letter, circulated by Rep. Jared Huffman (D-Calif.) and obtained by POLITICO, offers the first public signal from Democrats since the weekend’s attempted assassination on former President Donald Trump that scores of their own members remain deeply unsettled about the future of Biden’s candidacy.

“It’s a really bad move by the DNC. Somebody thinks it’s a clever way to lock down debate and I guess by dint of sheer force, achieve unity, but it doesn’t work that way,” Huffman said in an interview. He declined to confirm the existence of a letter.

This market resolves YES if a public letter opposing the early nomination plan is signed by at least 20 House Members or Senators who caucus with the Democratic Party before market close at the end of Sunday, July 21st. 

Multiple such letters with a combined total of 20 lawmaker's signatures would also be sufficient to resolve this market to YES. 

If these criteria are not met by market close, this market resolves NO.

Resolution source for the outcome: https://www.nytimes.com/interactive/2024/us/elections/biden-drop-out-democrats.html

If at any point before midnight July 20 Central Time, it shows 10 or more Dem Senators, this market will resolve to yes. Otherwise, it will resolve to no.

Suppose the following is true: At least 20 House/Senate Democrats sign a public letter opposing the plan to virtually nominate Biden early. Then, will 10 or more Democratic Senators call for Biden to drop out before July 20?

metadata.chain_of_thought: The scenario describes a situation where at least 20 House/Senate Democrats have signed a public letter opposing President Biden's early nomination. This indicates a significant level of dissent within the party, which could lead to increased pressure on Democratic Senators to take a stand, especially if they perceive that their constituents or party base are unsettled about Biden's candidacy. Given that the opposition is already organized and public, it is plausible that this dissent could manifest in calls for Biden to drop out, especially from at least 10 Democratic Senators. Historical patterns show that party unity can fracture under pressure, particularly when there are strong sentiments against a sitting president's nomination. Therefore, if there is already a public letter with substantial support, it is reasonable to believe that it could galvanize further action among Senate Democrats.

question.title: Will both of the following occur: (a) At least 20 House/Senate Democrats sign a public letter opposing the plan to virtually nominate Biden early (b) 10 or more Democratic Senators call for Biden to drop out before July 20?
question.body:
(a) Context from Politico:

Dozens of House Democrats are organizing a plan to speak out against their own party’s effort to seal President Joe Biden’s nomination sooner than originally planned, which they argue stifles the intense ongoing debate about his candidacy, according to a lawmaker involved in the effort.

A drafted letter, circulated by Rep. Jared Huffman (D-Calif.) and obtained by POLITICO, offers the first public signal from Democrats since the weekend’s attempted assassination on former President Donald Trump that scores of their own members remain deeply unsettled about the future of Biden’s candidacy.

“It’s a really bad move by the DNC. Somebody thinks it’s a clever way to lock down debate and I guess by dint of sheer force, achieve unity, but it doesn’t work that way,” Huffman said in an interview. He declined to confirm the existence of a letter.

This market resolves YES if a public letter opposing the early nomination plan is signed by at least 20 House Members or Senators who caucus with the Democratic Party before market close at the end of Sunday, July 21st. 

Multiple such letters with a combined total of 20 lawmaker's signatures would also be sufficient to resolve this market to YES. 

If these criteria are not met by market close, this market resolves NO.

(b) Resolution source: https://www.nytimes.com/interactive/2024/us/elections/biden-drop-out-democrats.html

If at any point before midnight July 20 Central Time, it shows 10 or more Dem Senators, this market will resolve to yes. Otherwise, it will resolve to no.

metadata.chain_of_thought: The context provided indicates a significant level of dissent among House Democrats regarding the early nomination of President Biden. The existence of a drafted letter and the involvement of Rep. Jared Huffman suggests that there is a concerted effort to gather support against the nomination plan. Given that this is a politically charged environment, it is plausible that at least 20 Democrats could sign such a letter, especially if they feel strongly about the issue. On the other hand, the second part of the question regarding 10 or more Democratic Senators calling for Biden to drop out is more uncertain. While there may be dissent, Democratic Senators might be less likely to publicly call for a sitting president to drop out, especially given the political implications and potential backlash. However, the combination of both conditions occurring seems feasible, as the first condition (the letter with 20 signatures) is more likely to happen based on the current sentiment among House Democrats. Considering both parts of the question, I assess that the probability of both conditions being met is relatively high, particularly due to the strong indications of dissent from House Democrats.

question.title: Will at least 5 countries win their first Olympic medal at the 2024 Games?
question.body: This question resolves as **Yes** if 5 or more countries win their first-ever Olympic medal at the Paris Olympics, according to [credible sources](https://www.metaculus.com/help/faq/#definitions).

metadata.chain_of_thought: The likelihood of at least 5 countries winning their first Olympic medal at the 2024 Games can be assessed based on historical trends and the increasing number of countries participating in the Olympics. The Olympic Games have seen a gradual increase in the diversity of medal winners, especially in recent years, with more nations investing in sports and developing competitive athletes. In the Tokyo 2020 Olympics, several countries, such as Fiji and the Philippines, won their first-ever Olympic medals, which indicates a trend towards more nations achieving this milestone. Given that the Paris 2024 Olympics is expected to feature a wide range of sports, including new events that could favor less traditional Olympic nations, the chance of at least 5 new medal-winning countries seems plausible. Considering the growing competitiveness of emerging nations in sports, it's reasonable to estimate that at least 5 countries could achieve this feat. Therefore, I would assess the probability of this question resolving YES to be relatively high.

question.title: Conditional on at least 5 countries winning their first Olympic medal at the 2024 Games, will at least 5 countries win their debut gold medal?
question.body: This question considers the scenario where 5 or more countries win their first-ever Olympic medal at the Paris Olympics, according to credible sources. Given this condition, the question then asks: Will 5 or more countries win their first-ever Olympic gold medal at the Paris Olympics, according to credible sources? The resolution criteria for the condition is that 5 or more countries must win their first-ever Olympic medal. The resolution criteria for the outcome is that 5 or more countries must win their first-ever Olympic gold medal.

metadata.chain_of_thought: The question revolves around the relationship between countries winning their first Olympic medal and those winning their first Olympic gold medal. If at least 5 countries win their first Olympic medal, it suggests that there is a growing pool of nations participating in the Olympics and potentially succeeding in various sports. Historically, new countries often achieve medals in events where competition is less fierce or where they have developed specific strengths. However, the leap from winning a medal to winning a gold medal is significant. Gold medals are more competitive and often require a higher level of achievement than simply winning any medal. While it is possible that some of the countries that win their first medals might also secure gold, it is less likely that all five would do so, especially considering the competitive nature of the Olympics and the existing dominance of established countries in many sports. That said, the probability of at least 5 countries winning their debut gold medals, given that 5 or more have already won their first medals, is still plausible. The presence of new medalists can indicate a shift in competition dynamics, allowing for the possibility of some of these countries to excel further and claim gold. Considering these factors, I would estimate a moderate probability that at least 5 countries will win their debut gold medals if at least 5 have already won their first medals.

question.title: Will at least 5 countries win their first Olympic medal and at least 5 countries win their first gold medal at the 2024 Olympics?
question.body: This question resolves as **Yes** if both of the following occur at the Paris Olympics: (a) 5 or more countries win their first-ever Olympic medal, and (b) 5 or more countries win their first-ever Olympic gold medal, according to [credible sources](https://www.metaculus.com/help/faq/#definitions).

metadata.chain_of_thought: The question asks whether at least 5 countries will win their first Olympic medal and at least 5 countries will win their first Olympic gold medal at the 2024 Olympics in Paris. Historically, the Olympics often see new countries achieving significant milestones, especially in events where they have been developing their sports programs or have recently joined the Olympic movement. In recent Olympics, we have seen a trend of emerging nations succeeding in various sports, leading to first-time medal wins. For instance, at the Tokyo 2020 Olympics, several countries won their first medals, including countries like Kosovo and Fiji. The global expansion of sports and the increasing competitiveness of various nations suggest that this trend could continue in Paris. Moreover, the variety of sports available at the Olympics means that there are numerous opportunities for countries to win medals and golds for the first time. With the addition of new events and the potential for upsets, it is plausible that both thresholds (5 countries winning medals and 5 countries winning golds) could be met. Given these factors, I assess that it is reasonably likely that both conditions will be satisfied, especially considering the historical context and the nature of the Olympic Games.
